canonical_explanation.text: Electric current is the flow of electric charge (electrons) through a conductor. When a circuit is complete, current flows from the positive terminal of the cell through the external circuit to the negative terminal. Electric current has two main effects studied at this level: the heating effect and the magnetic effect. The heating effect occurs because current flowing through a wire generates heat; this principle is used in devices like electric heaters, irons, toasters, and filament bulbs. An electric fuse is a safety device that uses the heating effect - it melts and breaks the circuit when excess current flows. The magnetic effect of current means a wire carrying current behaves like a magnet. An electromagnet is a coil of wire wound around an iron core that becomes magnetic when current flows through it. Electromagnets are used in electric bells, cranes, and many other devices.
rules: Electric current is the flow of charges (electrons) through a conductor.
A complete circuit is needed for current to flow.
Standard symbols are used to draw circuit diagrams: cell, battery, switch, bulb, wire.
Heating effect: current through a wire produces heat.
Devices using heating effect: heater, iron, toaster, filament bulb, fuse.
An electric fuse melts when excess current flows, breaking the circuit for safety.
Magnetic effect: a current-carrying wire behaves like a magnet.
An electromagnet is made by winding a coil around an iron core and passing current through it.
Electromagnets are temporary magnets; they lose magnetism when current is switched off.
An electric bell uses an electromagnet to make the hammer strike the gong repeatedly.

questions.question_text: What is the symbol used for a cell in a circuit diagram?

options.text: Two parallel lines of unequal length
A circle with a cross inside

questions.explanation_correct: A cell is represented in circuit diagrams by two parallel lines of unequal length. The longer line represents the positive terminal and the shorter line represents the negative terminal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A circle with a cross inside represents a bulb, a zigzag line represents a resistor, and a rectangle can represent other components. The cell is shown as two parallel lines of unequal length.

questions.question_text: A battery is a combination of two or more:
questions.explanation_correct: A battery is made by connecting two or more cells together. Each cell provides a certain voltage, and combining them increases the total voltage available.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A battery is not a combination of switches, bulbs, or wires. It is specifically a combination of two or more cells connected together.

questions.question_text: In a circuit diagram, the bulb is represented by a circle with a cross inside it.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, in standard circuit diagrams, a bulb (lamp) is represented by a circle with a cross (X) drawn inside it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The standard symbol for a bulb in a circuit diagram is a circle with a cross inside.

questions.question_text: For electric current to flow, the circuit must be ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Electric current can only flow when the circuit is complete, meaning there is a continuous path from the positive terminal of the cell, through the components, and back to the negative terminal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'complete'. A complete (closed) circuit is required for current to flow. If there is a break or gap in the circuit, current cannot flow.

questions.question_text: When electric current flows through a wire, the wire gets:
questions.explanation_correct: When electric current flows through a wire, the wire gets heated. This is known as the heating effect of electric current. The amount of heat produced depends on the current, resistance of the wire, and time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wire does not get cold or heavier when current flows through it. While it does also get magnetised, the primary observable effect described here is the heating effect.

questions.question_text: Which of the following devices works on the heating effect of electric current?
questions.explanation_correct: An electric iron works on the heating effect of electric current. When current passes through the heating element (a coil of high-resistance wire), it produces heat that is used to press clothes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electric bell and electromagnet work on the magnetic effect of current, not the heating effect. A magnetic compass uses a permanent magnet. The electric iron works on the heating effect.

questions.question_text: The filament of an electric bulb produces light because it gets heated to a very high temperature by the electric current.
questions.explanation_correct: The filament (usually made of tungsten) gets heated to such a high temperature by the electric current that it glows and produces light. This is an application of the heating effect of current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The filament in a bulb glows because electric current heats it to very high temperatures (around 2500 degrees C for tungsten), causing it to emit light.

questions.question_text: The filament of an electric bulb is made of ___ because it has a very high melting point.
questions.explanation_correct: Tungsten is used for bulb filaments because it has a very high melting point (about 3422 degrees C) and can withstand the extreme heat produced by the current without melting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'tungsten'. Tungsten has the highest melting point among metals, making it ideal for bulb filaments that must glow at very high temperatures.

questions.question_text: When electric current flows through a coil of wire, the coil behaves like a:
questions.explanation_correct: When electric current flows through a coil of wire, the coil produces a magnetic field and behaves like a magnet. This is called the magnetic effect of electric current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A current-carrying coil does not behave like a battery, switch, or fuse. It behaves like a magnet because the flow of electric charges creates a magnetic field around the coil.

questions.question_text: An electromagnet is made by winding a coil of insulated wire around:
questions.explanation_correct: An electromagnet is made by winding a coil of insulated wire around a soft iron core. When current flows through the coil, the iron core gets magnetised and becomes a strong temporary magnet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wood, plastic, and rubber are non-magnetic materials and would not be used as the core of an electromagnet. A soft iron core is used because it becomes strongly magnetised when current flows through the coil.

questions.question_text: An electromagnet retains its magnetism permanently even after the current is switched off.
questions.explanation_correct: An electromagnet is a temporary magnet. It loses its magnetism when the electric current is switched off. This is because the magnetic field is produced by the flow of current, and without current, there is no magnetic field.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Electromagnets are temporary magnets that only work when current flows through the coil. Once the current stops, the soft iron core loses its magnetism.

questions.question_text: An electric bell works on the principle of:
questions.explanation_correct: An electric bell works on the magnetic effect of electric current. It contains an electromagnet that attracts and releases a hammer repeatedly, making the hammer strike the gong and produce sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The electric bell does not use the heating or chemical effect. It uses the magnetic effect: an electromagnet repeatedly attracts and releases a hammer to strike the gong.

questions.question_text: In an electric bell, the ___ attracts the iron strip (hammer) when current flows through it.
questions.explanation_correct: The electromagnet in an electric bell attracts the iron strip (hammer) towards the gong when current flows through it. When the hammer touches the contact screw, the circuit breaks and the electromagnet releases the hammer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'electromagnet'. The electromagnet is the key component of an electric bell that attracts the hammer when energised.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of an electric fuse in a circuit?

options.text: To protect the circuit from excess current
To make the circuit work faster

questions.explanation_correct: An electric fuse is a safety device that protects the circuit and appliances from damage caused by excess current. When the current exceeds a safe limit, the fuse wire melts and breaks the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A fuse does not increase current, store electricity, or speed up the circuit. Its sole purpose is to protect the circuit by melting and breaking the connection when excess current flows.

questions.question_text: A fuse wire is made of a material that has:

options.text: The same melting point as copper

questions.explanation_correct: A fuse wire is made of a material with a low melting point (usually an alloy of tin and lead) so that it melts quickly when excess current flows, breaking the circuit and preventing damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the fuse wire had a high melting point, it would not melt quickly enough to protect the circuit. Fuse wire has a low melting point so it melts readily when excess current heats it up.

questions.question_text: MCB stands for Miniature Circuit Breaker and is used as a modern replacement for fuses.
questions.explanation_correct: MCB stands for Miniature Circuit Breaker. It is a modern safety device that automatically switches off the circuit when excess current flows. Unlike a fuse, it can be reset and reused.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. MCB (Miniature Circuit Breaker) is indeed a modern alternative to fuses that can be reset after tripping, unlike fuses which must be replaced.

questions.question_text: Which component in a circuit is used to open or close the circuit?
questions.explanation_correct: A switch is used to open or close a circuit. When the switch is closed (on), the circuit is complete and current flows. When the switch is open (off), the circuit is broken and current stops.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A cell provides the energy, a bulb converts electrical energy to light, and a wire carries the current. The switch is the component that controls whether the circuit is open or closed.

questions.question_text: The magnetic effect of electric current was discovered by Hans Christian ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Hans Christian Oersted discovered in 1820 that a compass needle deflects when placed near a wire carrying electric current. This proved the magnetic effect of electric current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Oersted'. He was the Danish scientist who first observed that electric current produces a magnetic effect.

questions.question_text: Which of the following does NOT use the heating effect of electric current?
questions.explanation_correct: The electric bell works on the magnetic effect of electric current, not the heating effect. It uses an electromagnet to make a hammer strike a gong. Heaters, toasters, and irons all use the heating effect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electric heaters, toasters, and irons all work on the heating effect. The electric bell uses the magnetic effect of current, making it the correct answer.

questions.question_text: When excess current flows through a fuse, the fuse wire ___ and breaks the circuit.
questions.explanation_correct: When excess current flows, the fuse wire heats up beyond its melting point and melts, breaking the circuit. This prevents damage to appliances and wiring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'melts'. The fuse wire is made of a low-melting-point material that melts when heated by excess current, breaking the circuit.

questions.question_text: A student draws a circuit with a cell, a switch, and a bulb. The switch is open. What will happen?
questions.explanation_correct: When the switch is open, there is a break in the circuit and current cannot flow. Without current, the bulb will not glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An open switch means the circuit is incomplete. No current can flow through a broken circuit, so the bulb will not glow at all.

questions.question_text: Why does the coil of an electric heater glow red but the connecting wires do not?

options.text: The connecting wires carry less current
The heater coil has higher resistance than the connecting wires
The connecting wires are thicker and have no resistance
The heater coil is painted red

questions.explanation_correct: The heater coil is made of a material with high resistance (like nichrome), so it produces much more heat and glows. The connecting wires have very low resistance, so they produce negligible heat and do not glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The same current flows through the heater coil and connecting wires. The difference is that the coil has much higher resistance, producing more heat and glowing, while the low-resistance wires barely heat up.

questions.question_text: How can you increase the strength of an electromagnet?

options.text: By using a wooden core instead of iron
By increasing the number of turns in the coil

questions.explanation_correct: Increasing the number of turns (coils) of wire wound around the iron core increases the magnetic field strength of the electromagnet. You can also increase the current to make it stronger.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A wooden core would make a weaker electromagnet, decreasing current weakens it, and using a shorter wire without more turns does not help. Increasing the number of turns strengthens the electromagnet.

questions.question_text: An electromagnet can be used to separate iron objects from a junkyard because:

options.text: It produces heat that melts non-iron materials
It attracts only iron and steel objects and can be switched off to release them
It repels iron objects to a specific location

questions.explanation_correct: An electromagnet attracts magnetic materials like iron and steel. The advantage of an electromagnet over a permanent magnet is that it can be switched off to release the objects at a desired location.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electromagnets attract (not repel) magnetic materials and cannot melt or dissolve anything. The key advantage is that they can be switched on to pick up iron/steel and switched off to drop them.

questions.question_text: In an electric bell, why does the hammer repeatedly strike the gong instead of staying attracted to the electromagnet?

options.text: Because the bell has a timer that switches the electromagnet on and off
Because when the hammer moves towards the electromagnet, it breaks the circuit at the contact screw
Because the electromagnet keeps changing its poles
Because the hammer is made of a non-magnetic material

questions.explanation_correct: When the electromagnet attracts the iron strip (hammer), the hammer moves and breaks contact with the contact screw, which breaks the circuit. The electromagnet then loses its magnetism, the hammer springs back, reconnects at the contact screw, and the cycle repeats.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The repeated striking is caused by the make-and-break mechanism at the contact screw. When the hammer is attracted, it breaks the circuit, the electromagnet demagnetises, the hammer springs back, and the circuit is completed again.

questions.question_text: A household circuit has a 5A fuse. If the total current drawn by appliances is 6A, what will happen?

options.text: The fuse will melt and break the circuit

questions.explanation_correct: The fuse is rated at 5A, meaning it is designed to allow up to 5A of current. When 6A flows (exceeding the 5A rating), the fuse wire heats up, melts, and breaks the circuit to prevent damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When the current (6A) exceeds the fuse rating (5A), the fuse wire melts and breaks the circuit. This is exactly how fuses are designed to work - they protect against overcurrent.

questions.question_text: Nichrome wire is commonly used in heating devices because it has high resistance and does not oxidise easily at high temperatures.
questions.explanation_correct: Nichrome (an alloy of nickel and chromium) is widely used in heating elements because it has high electrical resistance (producing more heat) and does not oxidise (rust or corrode) easily even at high temperatures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Nichrome is preferred for heating elements due to its high resistance and resistance to oxidation at high temperatures.

questions.question_text: Why do we use symbols instead of drawing actual pictures of components in circuit diagrams?

options.text: Because symbols are universally understood and make diagrams simpler and clearer
Because actual pictures are too expensive to print
Because scientists want to keep circuits secret

questions.explanation_correct: Standard symbols are used in circuit diagrams because they are universally understood by scientists and engineers across the world. They make diagrams simpler, clearer, and easier to draw and read.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Circuit symbols are used for practical reasons: they are universally understood, simple to draw, and make circuit diagrams clear and easy to interpret for anyone who knows the standard symbols.

questions.question_text: An electromagnet is a ___ magnet because it loses its magnetism when the current is switched off.
questions.explanation_correct: An electromagnet is a temporary magnet because its magnetism depends on the flow of electric current. When the current stops, the magnetic field disappears.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'temporary'. Unlike permanent magnets, electromagnets only have magnetic properties while current flows through them.

questions.question_text: Which part of an electric bell is responsible for producing sound?
questions.explanation_correct: The sound in an electric bell is produced when the hammer (attached to the iron strip) strikes the gong. The electromagnet drives this mechanism, but the actual sound comes from the hammer hitting the gong.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the electromagnet drives the mechanism and the battery provides energy, the sound is actually produced when the hammer strikes the gong.

questions.question_text: A blown fuse should be replaced with a thick copper wire to prevent it from blowing again.
questions.explanation_correct: A blown fuse should never be replaced with thick copper wire. Copper wire has a high melting point and would not melt even with excess current, defeating the purpose of the fuse and risking fire or damage to appliances. Always replace with a fuse of the correct rating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false and describes a dangerous practice. A thick copper wire would not melt to break the circuit during overcurrent. Always use a proper fuse wire of the correct rating.

questions.question_text: The heating element of an electric iron is made of an alloy called ___, which has high resistance.
questions.explanation_correct: Nichrome is the alloy (made of nickel and chromium) used in heating elements of devices like electric irons, heaters, and toasters. It has high resistance and does not oxidise easily at high temperatures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'nichrome'. This alloy of nickel and chromium is ideal for heating elements due to its high electrical resistance.

questions.question_text: What advantage does an electromagnet have over a permanent magnet?

options.text: An electromagnet can be switched on and off
An electromagnet does not need electricity
An electromagnet works only with iron

questions.explanation_correct: The main advantage of an electromagnet over a permanent magnet is that it can be switched on and off by controlling the electric current. Its strength can also be varied by changing the current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electromagnet's key advantage is that it can be controlled: switched on/off and its strength varied. It does need electricity (unlike a permanent magnet) and it attracts various magnetic materials, not just iron.

questions.question_text: In a filament bulb, why is the filament enclosed in a glass bulb filled with inert gas?

options.text: To make the bulb look attractive
To prevent the filament from burning up by keeping oxygen away
To increase the brightness of the bulb

questions.explanation_correct: The glass bulb is filled with an inert gas (like argon or nitrogen) to prevent the tungsten filament from burning up. If oxygen were present, the hot filament would react with oxygen and burn away quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The inert gas filling prevents oxidation of the hot filament. Without this protection, the filament would burn out immediately in the presence of oxygen. It is not about aesthetics, brightness, or cooling.

questions.question_text: What is the main advantage of an MCB (Miniature Circuit Breaker) over a fuse?

options.text: MCB is cheaper than a fuse
MCB can be reset and reused, while a fuse must be replaced
MCB does not need electricity to work
MCB can increase the current in the circuit

questions.explanation_correct: An MCB can be simply reset (switched back on) after it trips, making it reusable. A fuse, once it melts, must be replaced with a new one. This makes MCBs more convenient and economical in the long run.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The main advantage of an MCB is its reusability. It can be reset by flipping a switch, whereas a fuse wire must be replaced every time it blows.

questions.question_text: In an electric bell, when the hammer moves towards the gong, the circuit is ___ at the contact screw.
questions.explanation_correct: When the electromagnet attracts the iron strip (hammer) towards the gong, the strip moves away from the contact screw, breaking the circuit. This causes the electromagnet to lose its magnetism and the hammer springs back.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'broken'. The movement of the hammer towards the gong separates it from the contact screw, breaking the circuit.

questions.question_text: Draw the circuit diagram for a torch. Which of the following correctly describes the components and their arrangement?

options.text: Cells in series, connected to a bulb and a switch, all in a single loop
Cells in parallel, connected to a motor
A single cell connected to two bulbs in parallel
A battery connected only to a switch

questions.explanation_correct: A torch typically has cells connected in series (to increase voltage), connected to a bulb and a switch in a single loop circuit. When the switch is closed, current flows and the bulb lights up.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A torch has a simple series circuit: cells in series connected to a bulb and a switch in one loop. It does not use parallel cells, motors, or multiple bulbs.

questions.question_text: Ravi wants to make a simple heater using a nichrome wire, a battery, and connecting wires. Which arrangement would produce the most heat?

options.text: Use a long, thick nichrome wire with a weak battery
Use a short, thin nichrome wire with a strong battery
Replace the nichrome wire with copper wire

questions.explanation_correct: A short, thin nichrome wire has more resistance per unit length and a strong battery provides more current. More current through a resistant wire produces more heat. Copper wire has too low resistance, and an open circuit produces no heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For maximum heat, you need higher current and higher resistance in the heating element. A short thin nichrome wire with a strong battery achieves this. Copper has too low resistance, and an open circuit produces nothing.

questions.question_text: Meera made two electromagnets. Electromagnet A has 50 turns of wire and uses 1 cell. Electromagnet B has 100 turns and uses 2 cells. Which electromagnet is likely to be stronger and why?

options.text: A, because fewer turns make a stronger magnet
B, because it has more turns and more current from more cells
Neither will work because electromagnets need at least 200 turns

questions.explanation_correct: Electromagnet B has more turns (100 vs 50) and more cells (providing more current). Both factors increase the strength of an electromagnet. Therefore B is likely to be the stronger one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The strength of an electromagnet increases with more turns and more current. Electromagnet B has both more turns (100) and more current (from 2 cells), making it stronger.

questions.question_text: Explain why an electric bell stops ringing when the contact screw is adjusted so that it no longer touches the iron strip when at rest.

options.text: The circuit is always complete so the hammer stays attracted to the electromagnet
The circuit is never complete so no current flows and the electromagnet does not work
The gong moves away from the hammer

questions.explanation_correct: If the contact screw does not touch the iron strip at rest, the circuit is never complete. Without a complete circuit, no current flows, the electromagnet does not get energised, and the bell cannot ring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The iron strip and contact screw must be touching at rest to complete the circuit. Without this initial contact, the circuit is always open and no current can flow.

questions.question_text: A family uses a 5A fuse for a circuit with an electric iron (5A), a TV (0.5A), and a lamp (0.3A). If all are switched on simultaneously, what will happen?

options.text: The fuse will blow because total current exceeds 5A
The TV and lamp will work but not the iron

questions.explanation_correct: Total current = 5 + 0.5 + 0.3 = 5.8A. Since this exceeds the 5A fuse rating, the fuse wire will melt and break the circuit. None of the appliances will work until the fuse is replaced with one of a higher rating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The total current drawn (5.8A) exceeds the fuse rating (5A), so the fuse will blow and break the circuit. All appliances will stop working.

questions.question_text: Give one reason why electromagnets are used in cranes at junkyards instead of permanent magnets.

options.text: Electromagnets can be made much stronger and can be switched off to release the load

questions.explanation_correct: Electromagnets used in cranes can be made very strong (by using high current and many coils) and can be switched off to drop the load at the desired location. Permanent magnets cannot be switched off, making it difficult to release objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key reasons are controllability (can be switched on/off) and adjustable strength. Permanent magnets can attract iron but cannot be switched off, making them impractical for crane operations.

questions.question_text: An electric fuse works on the heating effect of electric current because the fuse wire melts when excess current heats it beyond its melting point.
questions.explanation_correct: The electric fuse is indeed based on the heating effect. When excess current flows, the fuse wire heats up due to the heating effect of current. Since the fuse wire has a low melting point, it melts and breaks the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The fuse uses the heating effect: excess current generates enough heat to melt the low-melting-point fuse wire, breaking the circuit.

questions.question_text: A student connects two bulbs and a cell using wires. One bulb glows but the other does not. What could be the most likely reason?

options.text: The non-glowing bulb may be fused (its filament may be broken)
Two bulbs cannot be connected to one cell

questions.explanation_correct: If one bulb glows but the other does not, the most likely reason is that the non-glowing bulb is fused (its filament is broken). A broken filament means there is no continuous path for current through that bulb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two bulbs can be connected to one cell. Wire length does not prevent a bulb from glowing in a normal circuit. The most common reason one bulb does not work is a broken filament (fused bulb).

questions.question_text: The strength of an electromagnet can be increased by increasing the number of ___ in the coil or by increasing the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The strength of an electromagnet depends on two main factors: the number of turns of wire in the coil and the amount of current flowing through it. Increasing either or both makes the electromagnet stronger.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answers are 'turns' and 'current'. More turns create a stronger magnetic field, and more current produces a stronger magnetic effect.

questions.question_text: What would happen if the iron strip in an electric bell were replaced with a plastic strip?

options.text: The bell would not ring at all
The bell would ring continuously without stopping

questions.explanation_correct: Plastic is a non-magnetic material and would not be attracted by the electromagnet. Without the hammer being pulled towards the gong, the bell cannot ring at all.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The iron strip must be attracted by the electromagnet for the bell to work. Plastic is non-magnetic and would not respond to the electromagnet, so the bell would not ring.

questions.question_text: Why should you never replace a blown fuse with a wire of higher rating than required?

options.text: Because it will not fit in the fuse holder
Because it may not melt when needed, allowing dangerous current to flow and risking fire
Because it will make the appliances work too fast

questions.explanation_correct: A fuse with a higher rating will allow more current to flow before it melts. If the current exceeds the safe level for the wiring or appliances but is still below the high-rated fuse, the fuse will not blow, potentially causing overheating, damage, or fire.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The danger is that a higher-rated fuse will not blow at the current level that could damage wiring or appliances. This can lead to overheating and fire. Safety, not cost or fit, is the concern.

questions.question_text: List two differences between the heating element wire and the connecting wire in an electric heater.

options.text: Heating element: high resistance, glows; Connecting wire: low resistance, does not glow
Heating element: low resistance, does not glow; Connecting wire: high resistance, glows
Both have the same resistance and glow equally
Heating element: made of copper; Connecting wire: made of nichrome

questions.explanation_correct: The heating element has high resistance (made of nichrome), so it generates more heat and glows. The connecting wires have low resistance (made of copper), generate negligible heat, and do not glow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The heating element has HIGH resistance (nichrome) and glows, while connecting wires have LOW resistance (copper) and do not glow. Option B has it reversed, and D has the materials swapped.

questions.question_text: A compass needle placed near a wire will deflect when current is passed through the wire, demonstrating the magnetic effect of electric current.
questions.explanation_correct: When current flows through a wire, it creates a magnetic field around the wire. This magnetic field affects the compass needle and causes it to deflect. This is the classic demonstration of the magnetic effect of electric current, first observed by Oersted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. This was Oersted's famous observation: a compass needle deflects near a current-carrying wire because the current produces a magnetic field.

questions.question_text: In a circuit diagram, the longer line in the symbol of a cell represents the ___ terminal.
questions.explanation_correct: In the standard symbol for a cell (two parallel lines of unequal length), the longer line represents the positive terminal and the shorter, thicker line represents the negative terminal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'positive'. The longer line in the cell symbol always represents the positive terminal, while the shorter line is the negative terminal.
